Professional Career

Beyond competitive programming, Bruce Merry has built a distinguished career in software engineering and high-performance computing, with a focus on projects that leverage his algorithmic expertise.

Current Role

Since August 2014, Merry has been a Senior Science Processing Developer at the South African Radio Astronomy Observatory (SARAO), where he works on the Square Kilometre Array (SKA) and MeerKAT projects. These initiatives involve developing software for large-scale radio telescopes, requiring expertise in high-performance computing, concurrent programming, and data processing.

His work at SARAO includes:

  • Developing high-performance networking libraries using tools like Boost.Python to interface Python with C++ for efficient data processing.
  • Contributing to the SPEAD (Streaming Protocol for Exchanging Astronomical Data) protocol, which facilitates high-speed data transfer for radio astronomy applications.
  • Applying concurrent programming techniques, such as Python’s asyncio framework, to handle multiple tasks efficiently in scientific computing workflows.

Merry’s contributions to SARAO have been recognized through his publications, with over 4,133 citations on Google Scholar, primarily in the fields of high-performance computing and radio astronomy.

Previous Roles

  • ARM (2008–2011): Merry worked on GPU products at ARM, applying his expertise in low-level programming and optimization to enhance graphics processing technologies.
  • Postdoctoral Fellowship at UCT (2011–2014): After returning to Cape Town, Merry conducted research at UCT, focusing on advanced computational techniques and mentoring students.
  • Conference Presentations: Merry has shared his expertise at conferences like PyConZA, where he delivered talks on topics such as Boost.Python (2015) and asyncio (2018). These presentations highlight his ability to bridge theoretical concepts with practical applications.
